data.title: Carlisle Cathedral
data.meta_description:
Carlisle Cathedral | 216 followers on LinkedIn. Anglican Cathedral and former Augustinian Priory of St Mary (1122). Cathedral (1133 - date). Over 900 years of history | Discover, experience and enjoy: over 900 years of extraordinary history; our famous starlight ceiling; our treasury exhibition; active family trails; an oasis of peace and prayer in the heart of the city with beautiful monastic gardens, award-winning caf√© and unique gift shop.

There are fascinating stories of faith, hope and love to discover here. They point to God who is at work among us now and who welcomes all.
data.text:
We are delighted that Robbie Anson - former Chorister, Consort Member and Deputy Lay Clerk at Carlisle Cathedral - has secured a Choral Scholarship at King's College, Cambridge where he has been offered a place to read Music. The Choir of King's College is one of most well-renowned representatives of English choral tradition and most famous for its Christmas television and radio broadcasts. Robbie said "I am very grateful to the music department at Carlisle Cathedral. Without their support and investment in me, I wouldn't have felt as confident to apply for King's. It is of particular note that the Consort Choir under the directorship of Ed Taylor, enables male voices to continue to develop through their teenage years. I am really looking forward to the move to Cambridge, but will miss the Cathedral family who have been such a huge part of my life for many years" Robbie leaves for Cambridge in September, but can be found working in the Carlisle Cathedral Cafe until then. Congratulations Robbie! üåü

We wish to congratulate our curate, The Reverend Dr Belinda Stanley, who has been appointed Cathedral Pastor at Hereford Cathedral, subject to the usual checks. The Dean & Chapter are grateful to Belinda for all she has contributed to the life of the cathedral and wish her well in her new role in the Diocese of Hereford. Canon Michael Manley, the Canon Missioner who has guided Belinda‚Äôs training at the Cathedral, said ‚ÄúIt has been a privilege to work with Belinda and her pastoral heart has made a real difference to so many people's lives. We will really miss her, but we know that our loss will be Hereford's gain‚Äù. Belinda will take up her new role in the early autumn and her last service in the Cathedral will be on Sunday 8 September at 10.30am. Please pray for Belinda as she prepares to move house and to take up her new role.

The person in charge of a major Cumbrian hospice has been appointed Carlisle Cathedral‚Äôs new Lay Safeguarding Lead. Julie Clayton is the Chief Executive at Eden Valley Hospice and Jigsaw, Cumbria's Children's Hospice. Born and brought up in Carlisle, she has also worked for the BBC and the NHS with a focus on community involvement. The voluntary role of Cathedral Lay Safeguarding Lead acts as a point of contact on Safeguarding matters at the Cathedral and is independent from the Cathedral Chapter and the Church of England. The role was previously held by David Allen, who was recently elected as the Police, Fire and Crime Commissioner for Cumbria. Julie said: ‚ÄúI am really pleased to be supporting the team at the Cathedral to ensure the approach to safeguarding is effective. It is not only an important place of worship for Cumbria but is also an important part of our city life. I‚Äôm looking forward to working with the team to ensure its spaces are safe and welcoming for all.‚Äù The Very Revd Jonathan Brewster, Dean of Carlisle, said ‚ÄúWe would like to warmly welcome Julie to Carlisle Cathedral, in a role that supports our unwavering commitment to Safeguarding. In recent years we have worked hard, not least through our annual Safeguarding Season, to lament our past failings and to listen to those who have been affected by all forms of abuse. As we look to learn from the past, we are delighted to welcome Julie to this role as we seek to ensure the Cathedral is a safe, supportive and caring community for all. We would like to extend our gratitude to David Allen, who held this role for 5 years, for his care and commitment to all Safeguarding matters.‚Äù More information about Safeguarding at Carlisle Cathedral can be found on our website.

üåü Angels' View Tours are back this summer! üåü From Monday 22 July, tours are available each day (except Sundays). Climb up to our clerestory to experience the Cathedral in a unique way. Get up close to our medieval stained glass in the East Window and see the starry ceiling and the Cathedral from a new perspective. Please note this at-height tour includes steps and confined spaces. Tour duration: approx. 30 minutes. üìÖ Daily, from Monday 22 July ‚è≤ 11.30am, 1.30pm and 2.30pm ‚û° Tickets: ¬£4* / Children 8-16 years: Free. Available from https://lnkd.in/eqFxnQNT *a 15p per ticket booking fee will be added to all online bookings

We are pleased to announce that the Revd Canon Michael Manley, Canon Missioner of Carlisle Cathedral, has been appointed to a new role in the Diocese of Blackburn. As Vicar of St Thomas, in St Anne‚Äôs on Sea, Lancashire, Michael will provide strategic leadership to develop the mission and ministry of the parish. Michael said ‚ÄúI've really enjoyed my time at the Cathedral and remain grateful for all the love and care of my colleagues, the staff and people here, in the city and across the county. The call to move to St Thomas came as a surprise but I feel confident that it is where God now wants me to be. I will look back on my time here with enormous thankfulness.‚Äù Michael‚Äôs final service at Carlisle Cathedral will take place on Sunday 29 September. The Bishop of Blackburn will institute and the Archdeacon of Lancaster with induct Michael on Sunday 27 October 2024 at 3pm at St Thomas. Please do pray for Michael as he prepares to move house and take up this new role.

I've been waxing lyrical about these tours to basically anyone who gives me half a second to do so. Its a fantastic chance to see areas of the Cathedral which are usually out of bounds, and to learn more about the fascinating art of bell ringing. Bell Tower Tours - Saturday 20 July at 10am, 11am, 1.30pm and 2.30pm Tickets: Adults ¬£10 / 8 to 16 years FREE Book here: https://lnkd.in/e7xgjjTs (link in comments) (Please note that the tour involves climbing lots of steps and being in confined spaces, as you might expect. All children must be at least 8 years of age and be accompanied by an adult)
